<p>thanks aketitle</p>
<p><strong>Abstract</strong></p>
<div class="list">
<p><span> </span></p>
<p>This document provides a basic template for the 2-page extended
abstract and some submission guidelines. The authors’ names and
affiliations should not be included. <a href="#fn1" class="footnote-ref"
id="fnref1" role="doc-noteref"><sup>1</sup></a> Including an abstract is
optional, as the document itself is an extended abstract. If included,
an abstract should be a single paragraph.</p>
</div>
<p><span><strong>Keywords:</strong></span> Optional, Yet Potentially,
Helpful</p>
<h1 id="introduction">Introduction</h1>
<p>We have based this SDSS template almost entirely on the template for
the annual conference of the Association for Computational Linguistics
(ACL), whose template includes the following paragraph of credits:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>This document has been adapted from the instructions for earlier ACL
proceedings, including those for ACL-2012 by Maggie Li and Michael
White, those from ACL-2010 by Jing-Shing Chang and Philipp Koehn, those
for ACL-2008 by Johanna D. Moore, Simone Teufel, James Allan, and
Sadaoki Furui, those for ACL-2005 by Hwee Tou Ng and Kemal Oflazer,
those for ACL-2002 by Eugene Charniak and Dekang Lin, and earlier ACL
and EACL formats. Those versions were written by several people,
including John Chen, Henry S. Thompson and Donald Walker. Additional
elements were taken from the formatting instructions of the
<span><em>International Joint Conference on Artificial
Intelligence</em></span>.</p>
</blockquote>
<h1 id="methods">Methods</h1>
<p>In preparing the extended abstract, we strongly encourage using the
same four section headings seen here, namely, Introduction, Methods,
Data (or Results), and Discussion (or Conclusions). Use of subsections
is at the authors’ discretion; see Section <a href="#info-on-sections"
data-reference-type="ref" data-reference="info-on-sections">2.2</a>.</p>
<h2 id="font-sizes-and-layout">Font Sizes and Layout</h2>
<p>Extended abstracts should be no more than two pages, including
references, in 10-point Times Roman font and two-column format, and must
be submitted as pdf documents. The LaTeX template automatically uses the
<span><code>newtx</code></span> package if available or
<span><code>times</code></span> if not to select Times Roman. Please
avoid changing the font size except, if desired, in the case of an
extended quotation as demonstrated above.</p>
<p>Both LaTeX and MS Word templates may be downloaded by visiting the
conference website:</p>
<div class="center">
<p><strong><code>github.com/SDSS2020/SDSS-templates</code></strong></p>
</div>
<p>Margins should not be altered from those used in the template
files.</p>

<h2 id="info-on-sections">Sections</h2>
<p><span><strong>Headings</strong></span>: While it is permissible to
use bold print to introduce a paragraph as seen here, please use the
<code>\section</code>, <code>\subsection</code>, and
<code>\subsubsection</code> commands as in this LaTeX document. If you
are using MS Word, please duplicate the numbering and font-size
conventions in this document.</p>
<h3 id="numbering-sections">Numbering Sections</h3>
<p>As shown here, all sections, sub-sections, and sub-subsections are
numbered.</p>
<h2 id="citations">Citations</h2>
<p>In LaTeX, please use the <span><code>sdss2020</code></span>
bibliography style, as demonstrated by this example document. MS Word
users should duplicate the citation and reference section format seen
here.</p>
<p>Citations within the text appear in parentheses as <span
class="citation" data-cites="Nussbaum2018"></span> or, if the author’s
name appears in the text itself, as Nussbaum . Treat double authors as
in <span class="citation" data-cites="Wasserstein2016"></span>, but
write as in <span class="citation" data-cites="Brunner"></span> when
more than two authors are involved. Collapse multiple citations as
in <span class="citation"
data-cites="LaVange2019 Wasserstein2016"></span>. As alluded to above,
full citations should not be used as sentence constituents. For
instance, instead of</p>
<blockquote>
<p>“<span class="citation" data-cites="Arbuthnot1710"></span> found the
first <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-value ...”</p>
</blockquote>
<p>use</p>
<blockquote>
<p>“Arbuthnot  found the first <span
class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-value ...”.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Please make references complete, presentable, and consistent. When
using BibTeX, protect capital letters of names and abbreviations in
titles, as in {B}ayesian or {EM} algorithm, in your .bib file. For an
example, notice that the “FDA” in the title of <span class="citation"
data-cites="LaVange2019"></span> is typed as <code>{FDA}</code> in the
.bib file or else it would be incorrectly shown as “fda” in the
references section.</p>
<h2 id="footnotes">Footnotes</h2>
<p><span><strong>Footnotes</strong></span>: In LaTeX, use the
<code>\footnote</code> command<a href="#fn2" class="footnote-ref"
id="fnref2" role="doc-noteref"><sup>2</sup></a>. If using MS Word,
please separate footnotes from the text by a line<a href="#fn3"
class="footnote-ref" id="fnref3"
role="doc-noteref"><sup>3</sup></a>.</p>
<h1 id="dataresults">Data/Results</h1>
<p>We encourage the selective use of tables and/or figures as
appropriate.</p>
<h2 id="graphics-and-tables">Graphics and Tables</h2>
<p>Place figures and tables in the paper near where they are first
discussed, rather than at the end, if possible. It is acceptable that
wide illustrations may run across both columns. The use of color is
allowed in extended abstract graphics.</p>
<figure id="bayespic">
<div class="center">
<img src="bayes" />
</div>
<figcaption>Ironically, Thomas Bayes was never asked to provide
additional simulation studies in the Results sections of his
papers.</figcaption>
</figure>
<h2 id="captions">Captions</h2>
<p>Provide a caption below every figure and table; number each one
sequentially in the form shown in Figure <a href="#bayespic"
data-reference-type="ref" data-reference="bayespic">1</a> and Table <a
href="#fontsizes" data-reference-type="ref"
data-reference="fontsizes">1</a>.</p>
<h1 id="discussionconclusions">Discussion/Conclusions</h1>
<h2 id="appendices-and-acknowledgements">Appendices and
Acknowledgements</h2>
<p>Please avoid the use of appendices and acknowledgements as separate
sections. Any pertinent material should be included in the body of the
extended abstract rather than in an appendix. If acknowledgements are
necessary, then they should be made using footnotes.</p>
<h2 id="computer-code">Computer Code</h2>
<p>If you wish to provide links to accompanying code, this is allowable
because SDSS encourages best practices for reproducible research.
However, all conclusions and exposition relevant to the refereeing
process should appear in the body of the extended abstract; furthermore,
we cannot guarantee that code will be checked or even consulted during
the refereeing process.</p>
<h2 id="refereeing-decisions">Refereeing Decisions</h2>
<p>The review is <strong>anonymous</strong>. Accepted papers must be
presented in person at SDSS in St. Louis from May 23 to 26, 2023.
Accepted papers’ authors will be notified in plenty of time to make
registration and travel arrangements and for papers not accepted to
submit a lightning abstract to the conference if they so choose.</p>
